data.title: MPLX LP SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
MPLX LP, a diversified master limited partnership formed by Marathon Petroleum Corporation (MPC) in 2012, has released its 2025 10-K report. The report highlights the company's robust financial performance, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces in the midstream energy sector. MPLX LP owns and operates midstream energy infrastructure and logistics assets, providing fuels distribution services across the United States.

Financial Highlights

MPLX LP reported strong financial performance for 2025, with significant increases across key metrics:

  • Total Revenues and Other Income: $12,998 million, reflecting a $1,065 million increase from 2024, primarily due to increased service revenue, rental income, and product-related revenue.
  • Income from Operations: $5,943 million, an increase of $655 million from 2024, driven by higher revenues and gains from acquisitions.
  • Net Income: $4,952 million, up by $595 million compared to 2024, primarily due to gains from the BANGL Acquisition and improved operational performance.
  • Net Income Attributable to MPLX LP: $4,912 million, reflecting a $595 million increase from 2024, supported by higher throughput and benefits from recent acquisitions.
  • Adjusted EBITDA Attributable to MPLX LP: $7,017 million, an increase of $253 million from 2024, indicating strong operational performance and effective cost management.
  • DCF Attributable to MPLX: $5,791 million, up by $94 million from 2024, highlighting the partnership's ability to generate sufficient cash flow to support distributions.

Business Highlights

MPLX LP's business performance in 2025 was marked by significant operational achievements and strategic expansions:

  • Business Overview: MPLX LP is a diversified, large-cap master limited partnership formed by Marathon Petroleum Corporation (MPC) in 2012. It owns and operates midstream energy infrastructure and logistics assets, providing fuels distribution services across the United States.
  • Operational Segments: The company operates in two main segments: Crude Oil and Products Logistics, and Natural Gas and NGL Services. The Crude Oil and Products Logistics segment focuses on the gathering, transportation, storage, and distribution of crude oil, refined products, and renewables. The Natural Gas and NGL Services segment provides services from wellhead to market, including gathering, treating, processing, and transportation of natural gas and NGLs.
  • Strategic Relationship with MPC: MPLX maintains a strategic relationship with MPC, which is a significant source of revenue. As of December 31, 2025, MPC owned approximately 64% of MPLX's outstanding common units and accounted for 48% of total revenues.
  • Asset Expansion: In 2025, MPLX expanded its crude oil value chain by acquiring gathering businesses from Whiptail Midstream, LLC, and completed the acquisition of Northwind Midstream for $2.4 billion. Additionally, MPLX acquired the remaining 55% interest in BANGL, LLC.
  • Geographical Performance: MPLX's assets are strategically positioned throughout the United States, with significant operations in key regions such as the Marcellus Shale, Permian Basin, Utica Shale, STACK Shale, and Bakken Shale.
  • Commitment to Sustainability: MPLX is committed to sustainability, focusing on lowering carbon intensity, conserving natural resources, and investing in emerging technologies to enhance operational efficiency and environmental stewardship.
  • Future Outlook: MPLX anticipates continued growth in natural gas demand, driven by increased electricity generation needs. The company is well-positioned to support the development plans of its producer-customers, particularly in the Marcellus and Utica regions.
  • Operational Excellence: MPLX is focused on achieving operational excellence by reducing costs, improving efficiency, and optimizing capital allocation to ensure high returns on investment.
  • Safety and Reliability: The company prioritizes safety and reliability in its operations, implementing structural changes to improve cost competitiveness while maintaining safe and reliable operations.

Strategic Initiatives

MPLX LP undertook several strategic initiatives in 2025 to enhance its long-term growth and financial stability:

  • Strategic Acquisitions: MPLX acquired Northwind Midstream for $2.4 billion and the remaining 55% interest in BANGL, LLC for $703 million. The company also expanded its crude oil value chain by acquiring gathering businesses from Whiptail Midstream, LLC and increased its interest in the Matterhorn Express Pipeline joint venture.
  • Divestitures: MPLX divested its Rockies gathering and processing operations for $980 million, aligning with its strategy to optimize its asset portfolio.
  • Capital Management: MPLX issued $6.5 billion in senior notes during 2025 to fund acquisitions and general partnership purposes, while redeeming $1.7 billion of senior notes. The company increased its quarterly distribution by 12.5% in the third quarter of 2025, reflecting its commitment to returning capital to unitholders. MPLX also repurchased $400 million of common units and announced a new $1.0 billion unit repurchase authorization. The company maintained a strong liquidity position with $5.6 billion available at year-end 2025, supported by cash generated from operations and access to credit facilities.
  • Future Outlook: Looking ahead, MPLX LP plans to invest $2.7 billion in capital expenditures for 2026, focusing on expanding its Permian to Gulf Coast integrated value chain and developing new gas processing plants in the Marcellus and Permian regions. The company aims to maintain an investment-grade credit profile and expects to continue leveraging its strong liquidity position to support strategic growth initiatives and capital returns to unitholders.

Challenges and Risks

MPLX LP faces several significant risks that could materially and adversely affect its business, financial condition, results of operations, and cash flows:

  • Market Risks: A significant decrease in crude oil and natural gas production in the company's areas of operation could adversely affect its business. Fluctuations in energy prices, which are beyond the company's control, can negatively impact drilling activity, production rates, and investments by third parties.
  • Operational Risks: The company is dependent on third parties for the crude oil, natural gas, and refined products it gathers, transports, and stores. A reduction in these quantities could reduce revenues and cash flow. Additionally, the company may not be able to accurately estimate expected production volumes of its producer customers, leading to potential underutilization of facilities.
  • Regulatory Risks: Increasing regulatory focus on data privacy issues and expanding laws in those areas pose business, compliance, and reputational risks. The company is also subject to risks associated with societal and political pressures and other forms of opposition to the development, transportation, and use of carbon-based fuels.
  • Emerging Risks: The integration of artificial intelligence technologies into the company's processes presents new business, compliance, and reputational risks. Additionally, the company is exposed to cybersecurity threats and attacks, which can compromise its ability to operate and the confidentiality, availability, and integrity of data.
  • Financial Risks: The company has substantial debt and other financial obligations, which could impair its financial condition and ability to fulfill its debt obligations. Increases in interest rates could adversely impact the company's unit price and ability to issue equity or incur additional debt.
  • Environmental Risks: The company expects to incur substantial capital expenditures and operating costs to meet the requirements of evolving environmental laws and regulations. Climate change and GHG emission regulation could affect operations, energy consumption patterns, and regulatory obligations.

Management has identified several strategies to address these challenges and risks, including enhancing operational efficiencies, strengthening relationships with key suppliers and customers, investing in technology and infrastructure, and engaging with regulatory bodies and stakeholders.

SEC Filing: MPLX LP [ MPLX ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: Basis bids flat as rains aid winter wheat
data.description:
Basis bids for hard red winter wheat were unchanged in the U.S. Plains states on Thursday as farmers and traders eyed rain prospects next week that would relieve dryness in the winter wheat belt.

  • Warmer weather is expected to aid growth.

  • The winter wheat crop is expected to emerge from dormancy soon.

  • Roughly 50% of the U.S. winter wheat crop is experiencing some level of drought, up from 46% last week, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

  • K.C. May hard red winter wheat (KWK26) was last down 1-1/2 cents to $5.62-3/4 per bushel as of midday.

data.title: Cronos Group Inc reports results for the quarter ended December 31 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• Cronos Group Inc reported quarterly adjusted earnings of 8 cents​​ per share for the quarter ended December 31, higher than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of 2 cents. The mean expectation of two analysts for the quarter was for earnings of one cent per share. Wall Street expected results

  • Revenue rose 47% to $44.53 million from a year ago; analysts expected $38.72 million.

  • Cronos Group Inc's reported EPS for the quarter was breakeven results​.

  • The company reported a quarterly loss of $1.82 million.

  • Cronos Group Inc shares had risen by 5.3% this quarter.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • In the last 30 days, there have been no earnings estimate revisions by analysts covering the company.

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "buy" and the breakdown of recommendations is 1 "strong buy" or "buy," 1 "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell."

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for Cronos Group Inc is $3.19, about 13.2% above its last closing price of $2.77

This summary was machine generated from LSEG data February 26 at 06:36 p.m. UTC. ​All figures in US dollars unless otherwise stated. data.title: Markets Have Had a Wild Ride. Here Are the Factors That Could Bring the Next Surprise. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Teresa Rivas

After living through a pandemic, new wars, political upsets, and the rise of artificial intelligence — in the first half of the decade alone — investors may feel they're entitled to a few years of normalcy.

That doesn't mean they'll get them.

Although they may not come to pass, there are plenty of potential black swan events that could be lurking in the back half of the 2020s. A group of Citi strategists led by Daniel Tobon take a look at these "wildcards" in a new note Thursday, noting that they "don't expect many — if any — of these to actually materialize. However, they are probable enough that they cannot be entirely dismissed."

Increasing global fragmentation is one key worry. President Donald Trump's choice to use his second term to remake the role of the U.S. in the world has led to heightened uncertainty — chiefly around trade but touching on multiple factors from migration to climate change.

Citi expects tariffs to be a fact of life in the near-term, but there's always the risk that global trade and political tensions ratchet higher, leading to worsening relationships between both the U.S. and Europe and the U.S. and China.

That's not small potatoes considering "these are the three largest economies in the world and this scenario would have material ramifications for the global economy," the strategists write. It would affect trade first, but then quickly spread to other spheres and "would likely mean (substantially) lower growth in all three economies and consequently softer global growth."

The global economy has been remarkably resilient and may continue to adapt as needed. But if it gets pushed beyond that point "many countries (and companies) would likely face difficult and costly trade-offs in an environment of rapid decoupling of the world's largest economies."

There is also the chance that the U.S. takes extreme steps in regard to Latin America and/or Iran.

If the U.S. were to blockade all oil exports from Latin America and nearby nations like Mexico it would lead to severe dislocations to oil price benchmarks in the Americas vs. the rest of the world, and a shock on par with the 1973 Arab oil embargo.

Elsewhere, tensions with Iran could erupt into potential attacks on that nation's nuclear and missile facilities as well as its oil-related infrastructure, leading to retaliatory actions.

"Alternatively, Iran's fragile domestic situation could fracture into leadership succession uncertainties, breaking down into factions attacking or vying for control of the country and its strategic oil infrastructure, similar to the situation in Libya since 2011," the strategists note.

Europe is another wild card. While it's long underperformed the U.S. in terms of growth and earnings performance, the region could once again take the lead as it did in 2002-2007.

Given the Trump administration's moves, Europe has accelerated its inward focus, to the benefit of domestic supply chains, military spending, and manufacturing.

"Overall, Eurozone nominal GDP growth could inch up to 4.5% annually for the next four to five years," the strategists write, leading to higher earnings from European companies that support higher valuations for their stocks.

Then there's artificial intelligence. Recent trading has reflected fears that AI will take over whole industries in tech and beyond, leading to the Nasdaq Composite falling into the red year to date and big selloffs in everything from logistics to financials that's left the S&P 500 treading water this year. And leveraged credit markets also have plenty of AI risk, the firm notes, given its heavy exposure to software and insurance, two industries potentially most at risk from AI. But on the other hand, the potential for a bubble that ultimately bursts remains as well.

Citi thinks that we are in a bubble, just one that's not quite ready to pop, considering liquidity remains ample. Yet if the burst does come sooner rather than later, it warns that a "recession would be likely given that the wealth effect would be much larger than in 2000." The Federal Reserve would likely be pushed to aggressively slash rates, potentially to zero, leading to a Treasury rally and weakening of the dollar.

"Taking 2000 as a template, money would flow out of tech as well as most cyclicals, and into defensives (Healthcare, Staples), and rates-sensitive sectors (Utilities, Real Estate)," Citi writes. "Diversification across countries would be much less helpful, as in 2000, global equity markets were unable to decouple from the U.S. market, with emerging markets in Asia actually underperforming the U.S."

It's already been a tumultuous 2026 for the stock market, for the U.S. and for the world as a whole. Yet if the past few years have taught us anything, it's to expect the unexpected.

Write to Teresa Rivas at teresa.rivas@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Accenture Partners With Mistral in European AI Push — WSJ
data.description:
By Xavier Martinez

Accenture said Thursday it struck a multi-year deal with French startup Mistral AI to help enterprise clients deploy artificial-intelligence technology, with a particular focus on European companies seeking alternatives to U.S.-based providers.

  • Accenture stock was recently up more than 6%, on pace for its largest percent increase since April 2025.
  • Despite today's move, shares of the professional-services company are down sharply in 2026, more than 24%, and on track for its worst month on record, according to Dow Jones Market Data.
  • As part of the deal, Accenture will become a Mistral customer itself, deploying the startup's models across its roughly 784,000-person workforce.

This item is part of a Wall Street Journal live coverage event. The full stream can be found by searching P/WSJL (WSJ Live Coverage).

All prices as of 1825 GMT

EQUITIES

GLOBAL - An index of global equity markets eased after hitting a fresh record high on Thursday as concerns about lofty valuations of leading technology companies weighed on markets after artificial intelligence chipmaker Nvidia reported strong quarterly results.

MSCI's All Country World Index EURONEXT:IACWI was down 0.62% after rising to a record high of 1,063.86.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

NEW YORK - The Nasdaq led losses on Thursday, as a recent rally in technology stocks lost steam, with Nvidia's stellar results failing to enthuse investors and reigniting worries over the AI trade.

At 11:48 a.m., the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 112.27 points, or 0.23%, to 49,369.88, the S&P 500 lost 60.76 points, or 0.87%, to 6,885.05 and the Nasdaq Composite lost 355.32 points, or 1.53%, to 22,796.76.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

LONDON - Europe's benchmark index retreated from a record high on Thursday, as healthcare and technology shares weighed, while upbeat corporate earnings from the likes of Schneider and Indra limited the overall declines.

The pan-European STOXX 600 index closed 0.1% lower after hitting an intraday record high earlier in the session.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

TOKYO - Japan's Nikkei share average surpassed the 59,000 mark for the first time on Thursday, led by software-related shares as investor fears over disruption from artificial intelligence eased.

The benchmark Nikkei 225 Index rose 0.3% to close at 58,753.39, an all-time closing high, after rising as high as 59,332.43 in earlier trade.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

SHANGHAI - China stocks closed lower on Thursday, snapping a two-session post-Lunar New Year rally, as investors held off on major moves ahead of an annual parliamentary meeting next week.

China's blue-chip CSI300 index finished 0.2% lower. The Shanghai Composite index was flat at 4,146.63, surrendering its opening-hour gains.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

AUSTRALIA - Australian shares scaled an all-time high for a second straight session on Thursday, powered by heavyweight miners, healthcare majors and tech stocks on a buoyant earnings season and firmer commodity prices.

The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.5% higher at 9,175.30 points after breaching the 9,200 level for the first time earlier in the session.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

SEOUL - South Korean shares rose more than 3% on Thursday, hitting a fresh record high, as chipmakers jumped after Nvidia's earnings and automakers also extended a rally.

The benchmark KOSPI closed up 223.41 points, or 3.67%, at 6,307.27, the highest close on record and marking a sixth straight session of gains.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

FOREIGN EXCHANGE

NEW YORK - The Japanese yen rebounded on Thursday after the head of the Bank of Japan said the decision on whether to increase interest rates will be based on economic data, while overall movements in the market were subdued as traders waited for fresh catalysts.

The dollar index , which measures the greenback against a basket of currencies including the yen and the euro, rose 0.04% to 97.66.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

SHANGHAI - China's yuan firmed to a near three-year high against the U.S. dollar on Thursday despite the central bank's signal aimed at curbing the currency's rapid gains, as seasonal settlement demand continued to underpin a sustained rally.

The yuan finished the domestic session at 6.8397, the strongest suchclose since March 23, 2023.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

AUSTRALIA - The Australian and New Zealand dollars held firm on Thursday amid a general lift in global risk sentiment, while the Aussie got an extra boost as mounting bets for another rate hike fattened yield spreads.

The hawkish divergence saw the Aussie reach $0.7130 , having climbed 0.9% overnight.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

SEOUL - The won was quoted at 1,425.8 per dollar on the onshore settlement platform >KRW=KFTC>, 0.14% higher than its previous close at 1,427.8.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

TREASURIES

NEW YORK - U.S. Treasury prices edged higher on Thursday on the back of some safe-haven bids as investors grew nervous about tensions involving Iran, also pricing in expectations that the Federal Reserve will hold interest rates steady at least for the first half of the year.

In late morning trading, the benchmark 10-year yield fell 3.2 basis points to 4.016% , while 30-year yields slid 2.2 bps to 4.672% (US30YT=RR).

For a full report, click on

- - - -

LONDON - Euro zone government bond yields fell to multi-month lows on Thursday as risk appetite soured, impacted by heightened U.S.-Iran tensions, wavering sentiment towards the tech sector and jitters around U.S. import tariffs.

Germany's 10-year government bond yield (DE10YT=RR), the euro zone's benchmark, was down 2 basis points at 2.69%, its lowest level since November 28.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

TOKYO - Japan's shorter-dated bond yields rose on Thursday, reversing the previous session's declines, as hawkish comments from the Bank of Japan officials stoked bets of early interest rate hikes.

The two-year JGB yield (JP2YTN=JBTC) rose as much as 3 basis points (bps) to 1.245% and the five-year yield (JP5YTN=JBTC) jumped as much as 4 bps to 1.620%.

For a full report, click on

COMMODITIES

GOLD

Gold prices were little changed on Thursday as investors stayed on the sidelines ahead of the third round of indirect U.S.-Iran nuclear talks in Geneva, hoping for signals on whether the negotiations could ease geopolitical tensions.

Spot gold was up 0.2% at $5,181.29 per ounce at 11:23 a.m. ET (1423 GMT).

For a full report, click on

- - - -

IRON ORE

Iron ore futures struggled for direction on Thursday, as traders weighed reduced demand for feedstock from imminent production cuts versus signs that Beijing will implement more property stimulus measures.

The most-traded May iron ore contract on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange (DCE) ended daytime tradeflat at 748.5 yuan ($109.46) a metric ton.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

BASE METALS

Copper dipped on Thursday as rising inventories and a firmer dollar tempered optimism about a revival in demand from China, the world's top consumer of the metal.

Benchmark three-month copper on the London Metal Exchange was down 0.2% at $13,296.50 a metric ton by 1700 GMT.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

OIL

Oil prices rose more than $1 on Thursday as investors awaited the outcome of a third round of talks between the United States and Iran over the latter's nuclear program.

Brent crude futures were up $1.17, or 1.65%, at $72.02 a barrel by 11:55 a.m. EDT (1655 GMT).

For a full report, click on

- - - -

PALM OIL

Malaysian palm oil futures fell on Thursday, weighed down by rival oil price weaknesses in Dalian and Chicago markets and sluggish exports, while a firm ringgit also added pressure.

The benchmark palm oil contract for May delivery on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives Exchange lost 48 ringgit, or 1.18%, to 4,005 ringgit ($1,031.68) a metric ton at closing.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

RUBBER

Japanese rubber futures gained for the seventh straight session on Thursday, rising to their highest in a year on supply shortages as rubber enters its wintering season, bolstered by a rally in Asian stocks and firm oil prices.

The Osaka Exchange (OSE) rubber contract for August delivery , was up 3.4 yen, or 0.91%, at 377.6 yen ($2.42) per kg, hitting its highest since early February last year.

For a full report, click on

- - - -

data.title: Soybeans ease on profit taking after hitting 20-month peak on demand hopes
data.description:
Key points:
  • Biofuel demand supports soybean, soyoil futures
  • Corn futures decline due to profit-taking and low export sales
  • Wheat futures rise after three sessions of losses

By Karl Plume

U.S. soybean futures rallied on Thursday to their highest since mid-2024 on hopes for more U.S. biofuel demand and Chinese imports before the market eased in a profit-taking retreat.

Corn futures also declined on profit-taking and technical selling, and as weekly corn export sales fell below trade expectations, while wheat firmed following three sessions of losses.

Chicago Board of Trade May soybeans (SK26) were down 8-1/2 cents at $11.56-1/4 a bushel by 12:15 a.m. CST (1815 GMT) after the most-active contract rose to the highest point in 20 months. Soyoil futures (BOv1) rose for a fourth straight day and hit the highest level since mid-September 2023.

Both markets gained on news on Wednesday that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency would send its proposal for new biofuel blending mandates to the White House, with an expected rule to be finalised by the end of March. The move brings the market closer to ending recent uncertainty over demand for biofuels and feedstocks like soy.

A Reuters report on Thursday that the U.S. government plans to reallocate at least 50% of exempted biofuel blending obligations to big refiners, known as small refinery exemptions, or SREs, lent further support.

"If we have a reallocation of 50% of SREs, that is important and would mean that there's going to be greater biofuel demand," said Dan Basse, president of AgResource Co.

Questions about soybean demand from top importer China amid tariff uncertainty and ahead of U.S. President Donald Trump's trip to the country this spring kept the market on edge.

CBOT May wheat (WK26) was up 3-3/4 cents at $5.73-1/2 a bushel after retreating from a three-month peak at the start of the week. May corn (CK26) was down 1-1/4 cents at $4.40-3/4 a bushel, dipping from a 1-1/2-month high after weekly U.S. data showed a drop in export sales to the lowest in seven weeks.

data.title: REG - Legal&Gen UCITS ETF - Result of EGM
data.description:
RNS Number : 6104U Legal & General UCITS ETF PLC 26 February 2026  

26 February 2026

LEGAL & GENERAL UCITS ETF PLC

(an open-ended investment company with variable capital structured as an umbrella fund with segregated liability between its sub-funds)

RESULT OF THE EXTRAORDINARY GENERAL MEETING

Legal & General UCITS ETF Plc (the "Company") wishes to announce that the extraordinary general meeting (the "EGM") of the L&G Emerging Markets ESG Exclusions Paris Aligned UCITS ETF, was held at the registered office of the Company at 70 Sir John Rogerson's Quay, Dublin 2, Ireland, on 26 February at 3:00 p.m. All resolutions proposed in the Notice of EGM were passed as follows:

RESOLUTIONS

Ordinary Resolution

That the investment objective of L&G Emerging Markets ESG Exclusions Paris Aligned UCITS ETF (to be renamed L&G Emerging Markets Equity UCITS ETF) is hereby changed to reads as follows "The investment objective of the Fund is to provide exposure to the large and mid-cap equity market in emerging markets".

FOR

4,676,956

AGAINST

-

ABSTAIN

-

Number of shares of the Company in respect of which proxy appointments had been validly made:

4,676,956

Number of shares of the Company in respect of which the vote was directed to be withheld:

-

Accordingly, the proposed resolutions were approved by the Shareholders in attendance or represented at the EGM.

The changes set out in the circular dated 4 February 2026 are expected to take effect on or around 27 February 2026 (the "Effective Date").

Unless otherwise defined herein, capitalised terms used in this announcement shall have the same meanings as those defined in the circular dated 4 February 2026 which is available on National Storage Mechanism (NSM) https://data.fca.org.uk/#/nsm/nationalstoragemechanism.

FURTHER INFORMATION

J&E Davy (Listing Sponsor)

data.title: REG - Intl Con Airline Grp - Final dividend and return of excess cash
data.description:
RNS Number : 6102U International Cons Airlines Group 26 February 2026  

INTERNATIONAL CONSOLIDATED AIRLINES GROUP, S.A.

("IAG" or the "Company")

Final dividend and return of excess cash

IAG today announces its decision to recommend to shareholders a final dividend of €0.05 per share in respect of the financial year to 31 December 2025.

Together with the interim dividend of €0.048 paid in December 2025, this brings the total dividend for the year to €0.098 per share, which represents a total ordinary dividend of €448 million taking into account the Company's issued share capital, excluding shares held in treasury.

Subject to shareholder approval at IAG's Annual General Meeting, the final dividend will be paid from 29 June 2026 to shareholders on the register on 26 June 2026. The dividend will be subject to Spanish withholding tax at the applicable rate (currently 19% or €0.0095 per share), resulting in a net amount per share of €0.0405. 

IAG also today announces the return of excess cash to shareholders of €1,500 million to be implemented over the course of the next twelve months, starting with a share buyback of €500 million to be completed by the end of May 2026. An announcement will be made in due course with further details.

Together, these steps reflect the Board's continued confidence in the Group's strategy, business model and financial position, as well as the long-term prospects for the business.

Nicholas Cadbury

Chief Financial and Sustainability Officer

26 February 2026

LEI: 959800TZHQRUSH1ESL13

This announcement contains inside information and is disclosed in accordance with the Company's obligations under the Market Abuse Regulation (EU) No 596/2014.
